bestBHT.bht: The warning in this passage advises against clinging to present treasures, as some do in hopes of saving them until they are consumed and buried in the ruins. The need to be ready for the Son of Man calls for complete indifference to worldly interests, similar to the urgency and abandonment of earthly possessions demanded of Lot and his family. This also alludes to the catastrophic event foretelling the coming of the Messiah. Though it is uncertain whether an actual physical flight is implied, the focus lies on not returning back, but making a swift escape.

Henry Alford: 31.] refers immediately to the example of Sodom just related. In Matt. xxiv. 16–18, it finds its place by a reference to the destruction of Jerusalem, see there.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Remember, &c.—a warning against that lingering reluctance to part with present treasures which induces some to remain in a burning house, in hopes of saving this and that precious article till consumed and buried in its ruins."
The cases here supposed, though different, are similar.
Marvin Vincent: On the house - top. See on Matthew 24:17.
Philip Schaff: In that day, the same haste and abandonment of earthly possessions will be called for, which was required of Lot and his family.
The catastrophe immediately preceding the coming of the Messiah, which is described in Matthew 24:29-31, is here referred to.
How far an actual physical flight is implied cannot, of course, be determined.
Archibald T. Robertson: Let him not go down. The usual idiom here would be μη and the aorist subjunctive."
See Mark 13:15; Matthew 24:17 when these words occur in the great eschatological discussion concerning flight before the destruction of Jerusalem."
Absolute indifference to all worldly interests as the attitude of readiness for the Son of Man.
John Gill: let him not come down; the inner way of the house, from the top: to take it away"
let him descend by the steps...and make his escape directly to Pella, or the mountains
let him likewise not return back; to fetch them, but make the best of his way as he is
John Wesley: In that day — (Which will be the grand type of the last day) when ye shall see Jerusalem encompassed with armies.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Luke 17:31, the reference to the example of Sodom suggests a warning against clinging to present treasures, as some do in hopes of saving them until they are consumed and buried in the ruins. The cases presented here, though different, are similar. The verse emphasizes a readiness for the Son of Man that requires absolute indifference to worldly interests. This parallels the urgency and abandonment of earthly possessions that was demanded of Lot and his family. It also alludes to the catastrophe preceding the coming of the Messiah, described in Matthew 24:29-31. The implied physical flight during this time cannot be definitively determined, but the emphasis is on not returning back, but making a swift escape.

The warning in this passage advises against clinging to present treasures, as some do in hopes of saving them until they are consumed and buried in the ruins. The need to be ready for the Son of Man calls for complete indifference to worldly interests, similar to the urgency and abandonment of earthly possessions demanded of Lot and his family. This also alludes to the catastrophic event foretelling the coming of the Messiah. Though it is uncertain whether an actual physical flight is implied, the focus lies on not returning back, but making a swift escape.

The warning against clinging to present treasures and hoping to save them until they are consumed and buried in the ruins is a reminder of the urgency and indifference to worldly interests required for readiness for the Son of Man. This parallels the abandonment of earthly possessions demanded of Lot and his family. The verse also alludes to the impending catastrophe that foreshadows the coming of the Messiah. While it is unclear if a physical flight is implied, the emphasis is on not returning but making a swift escape.

The warning not to cling to present treasures, hoping to save them until they are consumed and buried in the ruins, highlights the necessity of being ready for the coming of the Son of Man. This readiness entails complete indifference to worldly interests, akin to the abandonment of earthly possessions required of Lot and his family. The verse also alludes to the cataclysm before the arrival of the Messiah, symbolizing the need for swift escape. Though it remains uncertain whether physical flight is implied, the focus lies on not turning back, but moving forward.

The warning against holding onto present treasures, hoping they will survive until the ruins, emphasizes the need for readiness for the Son of Man. This readiness requires indifference to worldly matters, resembling Lot and his family's abandonment of earthly possessions. The verse alludes to the cataclysm preluding the Messiah's arrival, urging a swift escape. While it is unclear if literal flight is implied, the focus is on not turning back, but moving forward without delay.
